title: COVID-19 and Schizophrenia

content: Toward the end of the pandemic, I got COVID-19, after two vaccines. I had a horrible headache and stayed in bed for a few days.

To manage my schizophrenia, my routine included taking my medication before going to bed, getting a good night’s sleep, keeping somewhat active, eating well, and keeping my stress level under control.
But with COVID, it was easy to forget my routine. I wasn’t being lazy or careless – I was sick with something else.
Something that shut down the world.

My biggest trigger is stress. When faced with COVID-19 in my home – not in The New York Times or stories from friends – I stayed calm. Even though, in my mind, I saw photos of patients in emergency rooms near breaking points. I held myself back from negative thoughts. Not having severe COVID symptoms helped.
My second layer of defense was remembering to take my medication every night, even though I was sleeping through the day. I still had a sense of time, even with COVID.

content: Besides that, I didn’t eat much or move around.
I thought how awful it’d be if my schizophrenia flared up now. Luckily for me, it didn’t.

My good habits helped me keep a healthy routine. I knew it was essential to keep my brain happy – by limiting stress and taking my medication – and I made sure to do that, even in the midst of dealing with something new.

As someone with schizophrenia, I worry about having to deal with another health condition in addition to my brain disease. Managing schizophrenia on its own is already not easy. Any complication makes it more challenging. Forming routines and good living habits help make managing additional health conditions less daunting.
